Title: "A' Soalin'"
Description: Peaked at #15 on Billboard's Christmas Charts 12/28/1963.[1] From the album Moving. Written by Paul Stookey, Tracy Batteste & Elaina Mezzetti. Contains an element of "God Rest Ye Merry, Gentlemen".[2]

Title:
"Adeste Fideles
(O Come, All Ye Faithful)"
Description: Peaked at No. 5 on the Billboard pop singles chart in 1925. This historic record was the first electrically recorded disc to create a popular impact, and featured the largest choir popular music has ever known: some 4,800 voices (according to Columbia Records).[3] Over 150 versions of this standard have appeared in Christmas LPs since 1946.

Title:
"Adeste Fideles
(O Come, All Ye Faithful)"
Description: Peaked at No. 45 on the Billboard Hot 100 singles chart on the week ending December 26, 1960.[4][5]

Title: "All Alone on Christmas"
Description: Peaked at No. 83 on the Billboard Hot 100 singles chart in 1993. From the 1992 film Home Alone 2: Lost in New York.[6][7]

Title: "All I Really Want for Christmas"
Description: Peaked at No. 2 on the Billboard Christian Songs chart in 2006.[8] From the album All I Really Want for Christmas.

Title: "All I Want for Christmas Is a Real Good Tan"
Description: Peaked at No. 30 on Billboard's Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart.[9][10] From the album All I Want for Christmas Is a Real Good Tan.

Title: "All I Want for Christmas Is My Two Front Teeth"
Artist: Spike Jones and his City Slickers
Description: Spent three weeks at No. 1 on Billboard's Records Most Played by Disk Jockeys chart in 1948 and 1949. Also peaked at No. 14 on Billboard's Children's Records chart and No. 18 on Billboard's Best-Selling Pop Singles chart in 1950.[11][12] Written by Donald Yetter Gardner.

Title: "All I Want for Christmas Is You" (1)
Description: Originally released as the B-side of Thomas's 1963 holiday hit, "Gee Whiz, It's Christmas". A new version recorded by Thomas peaked at No. 11 on Billboard's Christmas Singles chart in 1966.[13]

Title: "All I Want for Christmas Is You" (2)
Description: First released as a single in 1989, but didn't become a country radio chart hit until 1993. Re-charted in 1994–1997. Peaked at No. 31 on Billboard's Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart in 1999.[14][15] Melody is the same as Bobby Vinton's 1964 top 10 pop hit, "My Heart Belongs to Only You".

Title: "All I Want for Christmas Is You" (3)
Description: Peaked at No. 12 on Billboard's Radio Songs chart and No. 6 on Billboard's Adult Contemporary chart on the first week of January 1995,[16] and three weeks at No. 1 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart in December 2019 into early January 2020.[17] Written by Walter Afanasieff and Mariah Carey.

Title: "All I Want for Christmas Is You" (3)
Description: Peaked at No. 38 on the Billboard Hot Country Songs chart on the week ending January 8, 2011.[18] Also peaked at No. 24 on the Billboard Hot Christian Songs chart (week ending January 8, 2011)[19] and at No. 14 on the Billboard Holiday Digital Song Sales chart (week ending November 10, 2012).[20]

Title: "All I Want for Christmas Is You" (3)
Description: Peaked at No. 24 on the Billboard Hot Christian Songs chart on the week ending January 8, 2011.[21]

Title: "All I Want for Christmas Is You" (3)
Description: Subtitled "SuperFestive!" Peaked at No. 3 on the Billboard Adult Contemporary chart on the week ending December 31, 2011.[22] Also peaked at No. 86 on the main Billboard Hot 100 chart (week ending November 19, 2011),[23] at No. 20 on the Billboard Holiday 100 chart (week ending December 17, 2011),[24] at No. 51 on the Billboard Digital Song Sales chart (week ending November 19, 2011),[25] at No. 1 on the Billboard Holiday Digital Song Sales chart (week ending November 19, 2011),[26] and at No. 20 on the Billboard Holiday Streaming Songs chart (week ending December 14, 2013).[27]

Title: "All I Want for Christmas Is You" (3)
Description: Peaked at No. 1 for five straight weeks on the Billboard Adult Contemporary chart, from the week ending December 10, 2011, to the week ending January 7, 2012.[28] Also peaked at No. 99 on the main Billboard Hot 100 chart (week ending December 31, 2011),[29][30] at No. 3 on the Billboard Holiday Digital Song Sales chart (week ending November 12, 2011),[31] at No. 13 on the Billboard Holiday 100 chart (week ending December 29, 2012),[32] at No. 21 on the Billboard Holiday Streaming Songs chart (week ending December 21, 2013),[33] and at No. 35 on the Billboard Holiday Airplay chart (week ending December 31, 2011).[34]

Title: "All My Love for Christmas"
Description: Peaked at No. 61 on Billboard's Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart in 1999.[35][36] From the 1998 various artists album Country Christmas Classics on RCA Records.

Title: "Amen"
Description: Featured in the 1963 film Lilies of the Field. Peaked at No. 7 on Billboard's Hot 100 singles chart on the week ending January 9, 1965, and at No. 17 on Billboard's Hot Rhythm & Blues Singles chart on the week ending January 30, 1965. An updated recording by the group titled "Amen (1970)" was released in November 1969, peaking at No. 44 on Billboard's Best Selling Soul Singles chart on the week ending January 10, 1970, and at No. 110 on Billboard's Bubbling Under The Hot 100 chart on the week ending January 3, 1970.[37][38]

Title: "Amen"
Description: Peaked at No. 124 on Billboard's Bubbling Under The Hot 100 chart on the week ending December 26, 1964.[39]

Title: "Angels Among Us"
Description: Reached No. 51 on Billboard's Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart from unsolicited airplay, as a partial Christmas single from the band's album Cheap Seats. Charted again in 1994 and 1995.[40][41]

Title: "Angels We Have Heard on High"
Description: Traditional French carol known as Les Anges dans nos campagnes translated to English in 1862 by James Chadwick. Peaked at No. 21 on the Billboard Christian Songs chart in 2004. Chris Tomlin also had a hit version on the Christian Songs chart in 2006, peaking at No. 5.[42]

Title: "Another Lonely Christmas"
Description: Peaked at No. 5 on Billboard's Christmas Singles chart. Originally released as the B-side of Prince and The Revolution's 1984 single "I Would Die 4 U".[39]

Title: "At This Table"
Description: From the album Christmas: A Season of Love.

Title: "Auld Lang Syne"
Description: Peaked at No. 5 on one of the top-selling music charts in December 1921.[2][43] Written by Robert Burns as a Scots-language poem in 1788[44][45] and set to the tune of a traditional folk song (Roud no. 6294).

Title: "Auld Lang Syne"
Artist: Guy Lombardo and His Royal Canadians
Description: First recorded and released by Decca Records in 1939 (Decca 2478) and again in 1947 (Decca 24260). A Decca re-release charted on the Music Vendor Christmas list of 1963. Lombardo first performed the song on radio in 1929.

Title: "Auld Lang Syne"
Description: Subtitled "The Millennium Mix". Peaked at No. 7 on Billboard's Hot 100 singles chart on the week ending January 8, 2000.[46][47]

Title: "Away in a Manger"
Description: Peaked at No. 73 on Billboard's Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart on the week ending January 9, 1999.[48][49] From her 1987 holiday album Merry Christmas to You.

Title: "Away in a Manger"
Description: Peaked at No. 67 on Billboard's Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart on the week ending January 8, 2000.[9][50]

Title: "Away in a Manger"
Description: Peaked at No. 7 on Billboard's Hot Christian Songs chart on the week ending January 7, 2006.[51]

Title: "Babes in Toyland/March of the Toys"
Description: Written by Victor Herbert and Glen MacDonough.[52] Popular by Arthur Fiedler and the Boston Pops orchestra (1958). Later recorded by Doc Severinsen and the Tonight Show Orchestra (1991).

Title: "A Baby Changes Everything"
Description: Spent three weeks at No. 1 on Billboard's Hot Adult Contemporary Tracks chart.[53] From Hill's first Christmas album, Joy to the World.

Title: "Baby, It's Cold Outside"
Description: With orchestra under the direction of Ted Dale. Written in 1944 by Frank Loesser. From the 1949 film Neptune's Daughter starring Esther Williams and Red Skelton. Peaked at No. 3 on the Billboard Records Most Played By Disk Jockeys chart, at No. 4 on the Billboard Best-Selling Popular Retail Records chart, and at No. 6 on the Billboard Most-Played Juke Box Records chart in mid 1949.[54][55]

Title: "Baby, It's Cold Outside"
Description: With Paul Weston and his orchestra. Peaked at No. 3 on the Billboard Records Most Played By Disk Jockeys chart, at No. 4 on the Billboard Best-Selling Popular Retail Records chart, and at No. 8 on the Billboard Most-Played Juke Box Records chart in mid 1949.[56][57]

Title: "Baby, It's Cold Outside"
Artist: Ella Fitzgerald & Louis Jordan & His Tympany Five
Description: Peaked at No. 9 on the Billboard Most-Played Juke Box Records chart and at No. 17 on the Billboard Best-Selling Popular Retail Records chart in mid 1949.[58][59]

Title: "Baby, It's Cold Outside"
Description: With Sammy Kaye and his orchestra. Peaked at No. 12 on the Billboard Records Most Played By Disk Jockeys chart, at No. 13 on the Billboard Best-Selling Popular Retail Records chart, and at No. 17 on the Billboard Most-Played Juke Box Records chart in mid 1949.[4][60]

Title: "Baby, It's Cold Outside"
Description: Peaked at No. 22 on the Billboard Records Most Played By Disk Jockeys chart on the week ending August 20, 1949.[37][61]

Title: "Baby, It's Cold Outside"
Description: From Martin's 1959 album A Winter Romance (with orchestra conducted by Gus Levene). Reached No. 1 on the Billboard Holiday Digital Song Sales chart on the week ending October 29, 2011.[62] Also peaked at No. 17 on the Billboard Holiday 100 chart[63] and at No. 15 on the Billboard Holiday Streaming Songs chart on the week ending December 22, 2018.[64] First entered the Billboard Hot 100 chart at No. 45 on the week ending January 4, 2020.[65]

Title: "Baby, It's Cold Outside"
Description: With orchestra conducted by Marty Paich. Peaked at No. 91 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart on the week ending March 10, 1962.[16][66]

Title: "Baby, It's Cold Outside"
Description: Peaked at No. 26 on the Billboard Holiday 100 chart on the week ending December 31, 2011,[67] and at No. 6 on the Billboard Holiday Digital Song Sales chart on the week ending November 26, 2011.[68]

Title: "Baby, It's Cold Outside"
Artist: Glee Cast featuring Chris Colfer and Darren Criss
Description: Peaked at No. 57 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart on the week ending December 25, 2010.[69] Performed in the 2010 Glee episode "A Very Glee Christmas."

Title: "Baby, It's Cold Outside"
Description: Spent three weeks at No. 1 on the Billboard Adult Contemporary chart from mid December 2014 into early January 2015.[70] Also peaked at No. 14 on the Billboard Holiday 100 chart on the week ending December 13, 2014,[71] and at 78 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart on the week ending December 6, 2014.[72]

Title: "Baby Jesus Is Born"
Description: Peaked at No. 62 on the Billboard Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart.[73][74]

Title: "Baby's First Christmas"
Description: Featuring the Don Costa Orchestra. Peaked at No. 7 on Billboard's Middle-Road Singles chart and No. 24 on the Billboard Hot 100 singles chart in 1961, and at No. 13 on Billboard's Christmas Singles chart in 1965.[75][76]

Title: "Back Door Santa"
Description: Released on the 1968 various artists holiday soul album Soul Christmas.[16] Also recorded by Bon Jovi for the 1987 various artists holiday compilation A Very Special Christmas (though it was removed from later pressings), and sampled by Run-D.M.C. for their hit, "Christmas in Hollis" (which was also included on A Very Special Christmas).

Title: "Barefoot Santa Claus"
Description: Peaked at No. 9 on Billboard's Christmas Singles chart. Charted again in 1968. Features a children's chorus on backing vocals. From the album My Christmas Dream.[77]

Title: "Because It's Christmas (For All the Children)"
Description: Peaked at No. 38 on the Billboard Hot Adult Contemporary Tracks chart in 1991.[6][78] From Manilow's first Christmas album, Because It's Christmas.

Title: "Believe"
Description: Peaked at No. 1 for five weeks on the Billboard Hot Adult Contemporary Tracks chart, and "Bubbled under" the Billboard Hot 100 chart with a peak position of #112.[79] From the 2004 film The Polar Express.

Title: "The Bell That Couldn't Jingle"
Description: Written by Burt Bacharach and Larry Kusik. Paul Evans, Bobby Helms, Herb Alpert, Anita Kerr, and Bacharach each recorded the song as well, but only Vinton's version charted, reaching No. 23 on the Billboard Christmas Singles chart.[14]

Title: "Belleau Wood"
Description: Peaked at No. 41 on Billboard Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart in 1998. From Brooks's album Sevens.[73][80]

Title: "The Bells of St. Mary's"
Description: Written by A. Emmett Adams and Douglas Furber in 1917.[81] While the song has no lyrical relation to Christmas, its inclusion in the 1945 film of the same name has made it a popular choice for various artists' holiday albums.

Title: "Better Days"
Description: Despite its overtly Christian tone and obvious references to Christmas, this song managed to reach No. 3 on the Billboard Hot Adult Top 40 Tracks chart, and remains in regular rotation on hot adult top 40 stations.[82]

Title: "The Blessings"
Description: Peaked at No. 72 on the Billboard Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart in 1997.[40][83]

Title: "Blue Christmas"
Description: Peaked at No. 1 on Billboard's Most-Played Juke Box (Country & Western) Records chart in the issue dated January 7, 1950. Also made these other Billboard music charts in December 1949 (with peak positions shown): Best-Selling Retail Folk (Country & Western) Records (No. 2), Country & Western Records Most Played by Folk Disk Jockeys (No. 2), Records Most Played by Disk Jockeys (No. 23), and Most Played Juke Box Records (No. 26).[84][85] Written as a country song by Billy Hayes and Jay W. Johnson in 1948, and first recorded by Doye O'Dell that year. Ranks as the all-time number one holiday single on Billboard's Hot Country Songs chart.

Title: "Blue Christmas"
Description: Peaked at No. 9 on Billboard's Records Most Played by Disk Jockeys chart in the issue dated January 7, 1950. Also made these other Billboard music charts in December 1949 (with peak positions shown): Most-Played Juke Box Records (No. 18) and Best Selling Pop Singles (No. 21). Re-entered Billboard's Most Played by Disk Jockeys chart in December 1950, peaking at No. 20.[86][87]

Title: "Blue Christmas"
Description: Made these Billboard music charts in December 1949 (with peak positions shown): Best Selling Pop Singles (No. 11), Most-Played Juke Box Records (No. 13), and Records Most Played by Disk Jockeys (No. 18). Vocals by Russ Morgan and The Morganaires.[88][89]

Title: "Blue Christmas"
Description: From the album Elvis' Christmas Album. First released as a commercial single in 1964. Listed on Billboard's Christmas Singles chart each December from 1964 to 1970, as well as 1972, 1973, and then again from 1983 to 1985, peaking at No. 1 on this chart on the week ending December 5, 1964, and then again on the week ending December 22, 1973.[39] First entered Billboard's main Hot 100 chart at No. 40 on the week ending January 5, 2019, peaking at No. 24 on the week ending January 7, 2023 (following its third chart re-entry). Also made these other Billboard music charts (with peak positions shown): Country Airplay (No. 55), Country Digital Song Sales (No. 22), Country Streaming Songs (No. 4), Digital Song Sales (No. 47), Global 200 (No. 35), Global 200 Excl. US (No. 89), Greatest of All Time Holiday 100 Songs (No. 18), Holiday 100 (No. 12), Holiday Airplay (No. 9), Holiday Digital Song Sales (No. 8), Holiday Streaming Songs (No. 9), Hot 100 Recurrents (No. 3), Hot Country Songs (No. 55), LyricFind Global (No. 13), LyricFind US (No. 15), Rock Digital Song Sales (No. 5), Rock Streaming Songs (No. 1), and Streaming Songs (No. 19).[90]

Title: "Blue Christmas"
Artist: The Browns featuring Jim Edward Brown
Description: Charted one week on Billboard's Hot 100 chart at No. 97 (week ending December 19, 1960). Features a guitar solo by Chet Atkins.[91][92]

Title: "Blue Christmas"
Description: Charted one week on Billboard's Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart at No. 74 (week ending January 9, 1999).[93][94]

Title: "Blue Christmas"
Description: Peaked at No. 51 on Billboard's Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart (week ending January 13, 2001).[14][95]

Title: "Blue Christmas"
Description: Charted one week on Billboard's Adult Contemporary chart at No. 21 (week ending January 3, 2004).[96][97]

Title: "Blue Christmas"
Description: Virtual duet featuring Presley's archived vocals mixed with McBride's vocals and re-recorded instrumentation. Made these Billboard music charts (with peak positions shown): Adult Contemporary (No. 22), Country Airplay (No. 36), and Hot Country Songs (No. 36).[90]

Title: "Blue December"
Description: Peaked at No. 18 on Billboard's Records Most Played by Disk Jockeys chart in early 1952.[86][98]

Title: "Blue Holiday"
Description: Written by Willie Denson and Luther Dixon and recorded by The Shirelles in 1961. Later recorded by Aretha Franklin, and appeared in the 2002 film The Santa Clause 2.[99]

Title: "Blue Lonely Winter"
Description: Peaked at No. 11 on Billboard's Hot Country Singles chart in 1968.[100][101]

Title: "Blue Winter"
Description: Peaked at No. 24 on the Billboard Hot 100 singles chart and No. 7 on the Billboard Middle-Road Singles chart in March 1964.[75][102]

Title: "Boogie Woogie Santa Claus"
Description: Peaked at No. 12 on Billboard's Race Records chart.[103][104] Written by Leon René. Other versions recorded by Patti Page (1950), Inner Voices (1994), Dave Koz (2001), the Brian Setzer Orchestra (2002) and Brenda Russell (2003).

Title: "Breath of Heaven (Mary's Song)"
Description: From the album Home For Christmas.[105]

Title: "Call Me Claus"
Description: Peaked at No. 22 on the Billboard Hot 100 sales chart in October 2001, and later reached No. 55 on the Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart in 2002. Title song from the TV movie starring Whoopi Goldberg.[73][106]

Title: "Candy Cane Christmas"
Description: Peaked at No. 16 on the Billboard Adult Contemporary chart, and No. 32 on the Country chart in 2010.[107] Originally released on the various-artists CD Now That's What I Call Christmas! 4 in 2010, and later on Rucker's 2014 album Home for the Holidays.

Title: "Carol of the Bells"
Description: Mykola Leontovych adapted the music from the Ukrainian song "Shchedryk" in 1914. Peter Wilhousky rearranged the melody for orchestra and added lyrics he copywrote in 1936. The song was first made commercially available in a medley on Fred Waring And His Pennsylvanians' 1942 album 'Twas The Night Before Christmas[108] Straight No Chaser's version from their 2008 album Holiday Spirits charted Billboard's Holiday Digital Song Sales survey in 2010. A version by Kim Walker-Smith peaked at No. 13 on Billboard's Adult Contemporary chart in 2014.[109]

Title: "Carol of the Bells"
Artist: Ray Conniff and the Ray Conniff Singers
Description: Featured on his popular album We Wish You a Merry Christmas titled as "Ring Christmas Bells". His version peaked at #60 on Billboard's Holiday 100 in 2015.

Title: "Carol of the Bells"
Description: Mannheim Steamroller recorded a prog-rock version on their second Christmas studio album A Fresh Aire Christmas. Their version peaked at #44 on Billboard's Holiday Songs chart in 2010.[110]

Title: "Carol of the Bells"
Description: Composer John Williams conducted a version for the Home Alone: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack. His version charted at number 86 on Billboard's Greatest of All Time Holiday 100 chart's. It peaked at #47 on the Holiday 100 in 2017.[111]

Title: "Carol of the Bells"
Description: The first track on The Christmas Album has charted the highest on the Holiday 100 at #33 in 2008.[112]

Title: "Carol of the Bells"
Description: Peaked at No. 20 on Billboard's Hot Adult Contemporary Tracks chart in 1998.[13]

Title: "Carol of the Bells"
Description: Featured on their popular album That's Christmas to Me, their A cappella version peaked at #5 in 2013 on Billboard's Holiday Digital Song Sales chart.[113]

Title: "Caroling, Caroling"
Description: Written by Alfred Burt & Wihla Hutson.[114] Also recorded by Natalie Cole, Tennessee Ernie Ford, and the King Family.

Title: "Celebrate Me Home"
Description: Title track of Loggins' 1977 debut solo album. Released as a single, the studio version reached No. 64 on the US Record World pop chart in the spring of 1978.[115] A 2015 version by LeAnn Rimes featuring Gavin DeGraw peaked at No. 12 on the Billboard Adult Contemporary chart in 2015.[116]

Title: "Cherry Cherry Christmas"
Description: Peaked at No. 4 on Billboard's Adult Contemporary chart.[117] First single released from and title track on Diamond's third holiday album, A Cherry Cherry Christmas.

Title: "Child of God"
Description: Peaked at No. 95 on the Billboard Hot 100 singles chart.[118][119] B-side of Darin's hit single "Christmas Auld Lang Syne".

Title: "Children, Go Where I Send Thee"
Description: Peaked at No. 21 on Billboard's Hot Christian Songs chart in 2016. Another version by John Oates peaked at No. 29 on Billboard's Adult Contemporary chart in 2017.

Title: "Children's Christmas Song"
Description: Peaked at No. 7 on Billboard's Christmas Singles chart 12/11/1965.[120] Features a children's chorus on backing vocals.[121]

Title: "The Chipmunk Song (Christmas Don't Be Late)"
Description: Spent four weeks at No. 1 on the Billboard Hot 100 singles chart in 1958, and reached No. 5 on Billboard's Hot R&B Sides chart in 1959.[9][122] Written by Ross Bagdasarian (a.k.a. David Seville). The most popular novelty Christmas single in the U.S. through the 1960s. Launched a 50-year music career for the fictional character group.

Title: "C-H-R-I-S-T-M-A-S"
Artist: Eddy Arnold, the Tennessee Plowboy and his Guitar
Description: Peaked at No. 7 on Billboard's Country & Western Records Most Played by Folk Disk Jockeys charts.[3][123] Written by Eddy Arnold & Jenny Lou Carson. Also recorded by the Ames Brothers and Jim Reeves.

Title: "Christmas Ain't Christmas (Without the One You Love)"
Description: Written and produced by Kenny Gamble and Leon Huff. The song's original title was the longer "(Christmas Ain't Christmas New Year's Ain't New Year's) Without the One You Love". Reissued by the group's record label (Philly International) in 1973 following the group's huge success.

Title: "Christmas All Over Again"
Description: From the 1992 album A Very Special Christmas 2.[124] Subsequently featured later that year in the 1992 film Home Alone 2: Lost in New York.

Title: "Christmas Alphabet"
Description: Peaked at No. 25 on the popular records chart. Features orchestration by Dick Jacobs.[48][125]

Title: "Christmas at the Zoo"
Description: From the album Clouds Taste Metallic. Not intended to be a Christmas song, though the characteristic "jingling bells" are featured in the song, as well as talk of the holiday.

Title: "Christmas Auld Lang Syne"
Description: Peaked at No. 51 on the Billboard Hot 100 singles chart in 1961.[118][126] The B-side "Child of God" also charted for one week in 1960.

Title: "Christmas (Baby Please Come Home)"
Description: Included on the 1963 holiday album A Christmas Gift for You from Phil Spector. Written by Phil Spector, Ellie Greenwich, and Jeff Barry. First entered Billboard's Hot 100 chart on the week ending December 29, 2018, peaking at No. 15 on the week ending December 31, 2022 (following its fourth chart re-entry). Also made these other Billboard music charts (with peak positions shown): Global 200 (No. 22), Global 200 Excl. US (No. 52), Greatest of All Time Holiday 100 Songs (No. 31), Holiday 100 (No. 7), Holiday Airplay (No. 24), Holiday Digital Song Sales (No. 21), Holiday Streaming Songs (No. 6), Hot 100 Recurrents (No. 1), R&B Digital Song Sales (No. 6), R&B Streaming Songs (No. 1), R&B/Hip-Hop Digital Song Sales (No. 12), R&B/Hip-Hop Streaming Songs (No. 1), and Streaming Songs (No. 8).[127]

Title: "Christmas (Baby Please Come Home)"
Description: Released on the 1987 charity album A Very Special Christmas. Peaked at No. 45 on the Billboard Digital Song Sales chart on the week ending January 1, 2005, at No. 29 on the Billboard Rock Digital Song Sales chart on the week ending December 25, 2010, and at No. 30 on the Billboard Holiday Digital Song Sales chart on the week ending January 8, 2011.[128]

Title: "Christmas (Baby Please Come Home)"
Description: Peaked at No. 20 on the Billboard Holiday 100 chart and at No. 27 on the Billboard Holiday Airplay chart on the week ending December 29, 2012, at No. 12 on the Billboard Holiday Digital Song Sales chart on the week ending November 26, 2011, and at No. 15 on the Billboard Holiday Streaming Songs chart on the week ending December 28, 2013.[129]

Title: "Christmas Blues"
Description: Peaked at No. 18 on the Billboard Christmas Singles chart.[91] Also released as a single by The Chipmunks.

Title: "The Christmas Blues"
Description: Written by David Holt and Sammy Cahn. Also recorded by Jo Stafford.

Title: "Christmas Canon"
Description: Chord progression is based on that of Pachelbel's Canon in D major.[130]

Title: "Christmas Can't Be Far Away"
Description: Peaked at No. 12 on Billboard's Country & Western Records Most Played by Jockeys chart in 1955.[3][131]

Title: "Christmas Can't Be Very Far Away"
Description: Not to be confused with "Christmas Can't Be Far Away" by Eddy Arnold.

Title: "Christmas Carol"
Description: Written in 1986 and first released on Ewing's 1990 album Following Yonder Star. First charted on Billboard's Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart in 1996, peaking at No. 68.[132][133]

Title: "Christmas Carols by the Old Corral"
Description: Peaked at No. 2 on Billboard's Most-Played Juke Box Folk Records chart.[134][135]

Title: "Christmas Celebration"
Description: First charted on Billboard's Christmas Singles chart in 1964, peaking at No. 25. Charted again in 1967, peaking at No. 17.[46]

Title: "Christmas Children"
Artist: David Collings, Richard Beaumont, & Karen Scargill
Description: From the 1970 children's holiday motion picture based on A Christmas Carol by Charles Dickens Scrooge. Featured in the soundtrack composed by Leslie Bricusse.

Title: "Christmas C'mon"
Description: Peaked at No. 21 on the Billboard Adult Contemporary chart.

Title: "Christmas (Comes But Once a Year)"
Description: Originally released as the B-side of Charles Brown's 1960 holiday hit single, "Please Come Home for Christmas".

Title: "Christmas Cookies"
Description: From the 2001 various artists album Christmas Cookies. Peaked at No. 33 on Billboard's Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart in 2002.[121][136] Originally issued on the Target CD A Country Christmas 1999.

Title: "Christmas Day"
Description: Peaked at No. 22 on the popular records chart. Features Hugo Winterhalter and his orchestra.[58] Written by Benny Davis and Ted Murry. Released within a four-record album set titled Christmas with Eddie Fisher.

Title: "Christmas Dinner"
Description: B-side is "A Rootin' Tootin' Santa Claus".

Title: "Christmas Dragnet (Parts I & II)"
Description: Peaked at No. 13 on Billboard's Best Selling Singles chart.[137][138] A parody of Dragnet and the follow-up to Freberg's No. 1 hit from several months earlier, "St. George and the Dragonet". In 1954, the same record was re-issued under the title "Yulenet (Parts I & II)".

Title: "Christmas Dream"
Description: Peaked at No. 92 on the Billboard Hot 100 singles chart. From the 1974 film The Odessa File.[96][139] Como's last appearance on the Billboard Hot 100.

Title: "Christmas Dreaming (A Little Early This Year)"
Description: Peaked at No. 26 on the Billboard Pop Charts. Featuring the Axel Stordahl orchestra.[54]

Title: "Christmas Eve"
Description: Peaked at No. 2 on the Billboard Adult Contemporary chart in early 2018.

Title: "Christmas Eve in My Hometown"
Description: Earlier recordings by Eddie Fisher and Kate Smith.

Title: "Christmas Eve/Sarajevo 12/24"
Description: The song is a medley including "God Rest Ye Merry, Gentlemen" and a hard rock version of "Carol of the Bells". First released in 1995 on the Savatage album Dead Winter Dead, but the same recording was re-released in 1996 as a track on the Trans-Siberian Orchestra album Christmas Eve and Other Stories.[84]

Title: "A Christmas Festival (Part One)"
Artist: Leroy Anderson and His "Pops" Concert Orchestra
Description: Peaked at No. 22 on the pop singles chart on the week of January 3, 1953. Famous medley of nine songs arranged by Anderson: "Joy to the World"/"Deck the Halls"/"God Rest Ye Merry, Gentlemen"/"Good King Wenceslas"/"Hark! The Herald Angels Sing"/"The First Noel"/"Silent Night"/"Jingle Bells"/O Come, All Ye Faithful".[3]

Title: "Christmas for Cowboys"
Description: From the album Rocky Mountain Christmas. Written by Steve Weisberg. Peaked at No. 58 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart.[118][140]

Title: "Christmas Goose (Snowbird)"
Artist: Stan & Doug 'Yust Go Nuts at Christmas'
Description: Peaked at No. 7 on Billboard's Christmas Singles chart on the week ending December 26, 1970.[141]

Title: "Christmas in America"
Description: Reached No. 22 on the Billboard Adult Contemporary chart and No. 37 on the Billboard Hot Singles Sales chart.[142][143] Later appeared on the 2003 album Go as a hidden track.

Title: "Christmas in Dixie"
Description: The original version featured Alabama wishing you "Merry Christmas" near the end of the song. Lead singer Randy Owen re-recorded the song with Kenny Chesney in 2003.[40][144]

Title: "Christmas in Hollis"
Description: An original song written and recorded by the group for charity, with the music video a perennial favorite on the MTV through the late 1980s and 1990s. It first appeared on two 1987 various artist holiday compilation albums: A Very Special Christmas and Christmas Rap, with the former album to benefit the Special Olympics. The track samples the 1968 soul tune "Back Door Santa" by Clarence Carter.[134][145]

Title: "Christmas in Killarney"
Description: Featuring the Mellowmen on backing vocals and instrumentation by the Henri René Orchestra.[118][146] Another hit version was by Percy Faith and the Shillelagh Singers in 1950.[58] Also recorded on successful Christmas albums by Bing Crosby, Bobby Vinton and Anne Murray.

Title: "Christmas in My Hometown"
Description: Covered by Travis Tritt in 1992

Little is known about Becky except for the fact that she was five years old at the time of the recording; the B-side, "Go to Sleep Little Lambs" is credited to Bill Lamb, presumably Becky's father.[169]

It peaked at #10 on the Holiday Song chart in 2005 and at #25 on the Holiday 100 in 2007.[403] Released as part of a medley by The Ray Conniff Singers in 1962. "Jolly Old St. Nicholas/Little Drummer Boy" peaked Billboard's Holiday Song chart at #19 in 2005. Other charted versions include RuPaul (1994),[134] Restless Heart (1999),[389] Josh Groban (2007),[404] Wilson Phillips (2010), Richard Marx (2012), and for KING & COUNTRY (2017). A version by the Vienna Boys Choir also hit big when it was featured in the Rankin/Bass animated TV special of the same name.

Title: "'Til Santa's Gone (Milk and Cookies)"
Description: Peaked at No. 58 on Billboard's Hot Country Singles & Tracks in 1996. Originally released in 1990 as a single, and on the albums Home for the Holidays and A Season of Harmony with the title "Til' Santa's Gone (I Just Can't Wait)".[142][575]

Title: "Time Passages"
Description: The most popular song on the Billboard Adult Contemporary Charts in 1978 and 1979.[576] Though released in December 1978 with a theme of going home for Christmas, the song has largely lost its association with Christmas over the years and is now aired more often in general recurrent rotation (in classic hits formats) than in Christmas rotations.

Title: "Toyland"
Description: From The Doris Day Christmas Album. Based on the Victor Herbert operetta Babes in Toyland. Also popular as an instrumental by countless artists.

Title: "Trains and Winter Rains"
Description: Peaked at No. 27 on Billboard's Adult Contemporary chart.[577] Included on Enya's 2008 album, And Winter Came....

Title: "'Twas the Night After Christmas"
Description: Peaked at No. 67 on Billboard's Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart in 1997. Parody of the famous 1823 poem written by Clement Moore.[75][578]

Title: "'Twas the Night Before Christmas (A Visit from St. Nicholas)"
Description: A recording of Clement Moore's famous 1823 poem set to music by Ken Darby and orchestration by Harry Simeone, it first charted on Billboard's Best Selling Children's Records chart in 1949, peaking at No. 11, and again in 1952, peaking at No. 6. This first recording by Waring was released around Christmastime of 1942 on the 4-record album set, 'Twas The Night Before Christmas.[56] He went on to record it two more times; again for Decca Records in 1955,[579] and a third and final time for Capitol Records in stereo in 1963.[580] This 1963 recording became the most famous of the poem's musical adaptations.[581] The song also charted by Arthur Godfrey with backing orchestration by Archie Bleyer on Billboard's Best Selling Children's Records chart in 1950.[93]

Title: "The Twelve Days of Christmas"
Description: One of the most recorded songs each year. First known recorded version was by Bing Crosby and The Andrews Sisters in 1949. The comedy duo of Bob & Doug McKenzie recorded a parody of this song in 1981. Other popular parodies that still receive airplay on radio stations around the holiday season include "The Twelve Pains of Christmas" by the Bob Rivers Comedy Corp (1987), and "Redneck 12 Days of Christmas" by Jeff Foxworthy (1995).[75] During the Christmas season of 2008, a comical a cappella version by Straight No Chaser reached No. 5 on Billboard's Adult Contemporary chart.

Title: "The Twelve Gifts of Christmas"
Description: Peaked at No. 5 on Billboard's Christmas Singles chart. Comical parody version of the traditional English carol, "The Twelve Days of Christmas".[54]

Title: "25th of Last December"
Description: Peaked at No. 28 on Billboard's Easy Listening chart and No. 52 on Billboard's Hot Soul Singles chart in 1978.[58][582] Written by Gene McDaniels. Originally recorded for the 1977 album Blue Lights in the Basement. Flack re-recorded the song for her 1997 holiday album, The Christmas Album.

Title: "2000 Miles"
Description: Originally released as the B-side of the band's 1983 single "Middle of the Road", and then included on the band's 1984 album Learning to Crawl. Also covered by Holly Cole in 1989, and recorded by Coldplay in 2003 as a download single for charity.

Title: "Twinkle Twinkle Little Me"
Description: Peaked at No. 5 on Billboard's Christmas Singles chart. Charted again in 1966 and 1967.[121]

Title: "Twistin' Bells"

Description: Peaked at No. 34 on Billboards Holiday 100 in 2020.[584]

First entered Billboard's main Hot 100 chart at No. 92 on the week ending December 21, 2013, peaking at No. 12 on the week ending January 2, 2021 (following its third chart re-entry). Also made these other Billboard music charts (with peak positions shown): Digital Song Sales (No. 17), Global 200 (No. 8), Global 200 Excl. US (No. 14), Greatest of All Time Holiday 100 Songs (No. 22), Holiday 100 (No. 8), Holiday Airplay (No. 24), Holiday Digital Song Sales (No. 3), Holiday Streaming Songs (No. 8), Hot 100 Recurrents (No. 3), LyricFind Global (No. 12), and Streaming Songs (No. 9).[585]

Title: "Warm & Fuzzy"
Description: Peaked at No. 50 on Billboard's Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart in 2001.[93][587]

Description: Written for the 1966 Dr. Seuss TV classic How the Grinch Stole Christmas!.

Title: "What Are You Doing New Year's Eve?"

Other charted versions include Danté & The Evergreens (1960),[118] and Nancy Wilson (1965).[86][595] Recorded by many other artists, including Dick Haymes & the Les Paul Trio (1947), Ella Fitzgerald (1960), Ramsey Lewis Trio (1960), King Curtis (1968), Johnny Mathis (1969), Patti LaBelle (1990), The Stylistics (1992), Harry Connick, Jr. (1993), Barbra Streisand (2001) and Diana Krall (2005).

Title: "What Can You Get a Wookiee for Christmas (When He Already Owns a Comb?)"
Artist: The Star Wars Intergalactic Droid Choir & Chorale
Description: Peaked at No. 69 on the Billboard Hot 100 singles chart. A novelty record featuring Star Wars' Chewbacca and included on the 1980 holiday album, Christmas in the Stars. The artist is actually disco producer Meco Monardo.[310]

Title: "What Child Is This?"
Description: Peaked at No. 75 on Billboard's Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart in 1997. Included on the 1996 various artists album A Country Christmas.[9][596] Traditional 16th century English melody, known as "Greensleeves". Lyrics written in the 19th century by William Chatterton Dix. Also charted by Carrie Underwood (2009).[597]

Title: "What Christmas Means to Me"
Description: From the album Someday at Christmas. Later versions were recorded by Paul Young (1992), Hanson (1997), Al Green (2004), and Jessica Simpson (2004). In 2021, John Legend released a duet with Stevie Wonder that charted at #34 on the Holiday 100.

Description: Peaked at No. 7 on Billboard's Easy Listening chart and No. 53 on the Billboard Hot 100 singles chart in 1975.[294][599] Covered in 1976 by Johnny Mathis, whose version spent three weeks at No. 1 on the Official UK Singles Chart in late December 1976 and early 1977. The melody was originally written as "Soleado" in 1972.

Title: "Where Are You Christmas?"
Description: Peaked at No. 10 Billboard's Adult Contemporary chart, No. 26 on Billboard's Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart and No. 65 on the Billboard Hot 100 singles chart in 2001. From the 2000 live action film, How the Grinch Stole Christmas.[294][601] Originally written for and intended to be sung by Mariah Carey, but she was not able due to record label disputes.

Title: "White Christmas"
Description: Spent eleven weeks at No. 1 on Billboard's National Best Selling Retail Records chart and three weeks at No. 1 on Billboard's Harlem Hit Parade chart in late 1942. Written by Irving Berlin. Bing Crosby's original 1942 version featured the Ken Darby Singers and John Scott Trotter's Orchestra. The song debuted in the 1942 film Holiday Inn (sung by Crosby), then appeared in the 1954 color film titled after the song.[4][602] The original was re-recorded in 1947 and it is still the best-selling Christmas single of all time in the U.S. (estimated at more than 50 million sold through the years), and appears on numerous holiday albums as well. Other charting recordings in 1942 were made by Gordon Jenkins (#16), Charlie Spivak (#20)[141] and Freddy Martin (#20).[603] Spivak and Martin recharted in 1945 both peaking at #16. Crosby made #1 again in 1945 and 1947 with his single. [6] Elvis Presley's 1957 cover of the song garnered controversy when Irving Berlin called for his version to be banned from radio airplay.

Description: Peaked at No. 2 on Billboard's Christmas Singles chart in 1973.

Title: "Winter"

Description: Peaked at No. 23 on the pop singles chart in early 1953. Featuring the Mello Men on vocals. B-side to Jones's hit recording of "I Saw Mommy Kissing Santa Claus".[11]

Description: Peaked at No. 24 on the pop singles chart in 1942. Featuring Peggy Lee and Art Lund on vocals.[93] Also recorded in 1941 by Fats Waller. Later recordings include Jo Stafford (1955) and Tony Bennett (1968).

Description: Lombardo's version peaked at No. 2 on the pop singles chart in early 1935,[35][606] while a version by Ted Weems and his Orchestra peaked at No. 13 on the pop singles chart.[56][607] Written in 1934 by Felix Bernard (composer) and Richard B. Smith (lyricist). Covered by hundreds of artists. Other charted hit versions include The Andrews Sisters with Guy Lombardo (1946),[3] Pat Green (2003),[197] and Newsboys (2010). Dolly Parton released the medley "Sleigh Ride/Winter Wonderland" that reached #6 on Billboard's Christmas Hits singles chart in 1984. In 2014, Pentatonix released the medley "Winter Wonderland/Don't Worry Be Happy" featuring Tori Kelly from the album That's Christmas to Me that peaked at #31 on the Holiday 100[113]

Title: "Winter Wonderland"

Title: "The Working Elf Blues"

Title: "Wrapped in Red"
Description: Peaked at No. 2 on Billboard's Adult Contemporary chart in 2014. First released on Clarkson's 2013 holiday album of the same name.[617]

Title: "Yes, Patricia, There Is a Santa Claus"
Description: Peaked at No. 14 on Billboard's Christmas Singles chart in 1965. Inspired by the famous 1897 newspaper editorial, "Yes, Virginia, there is a Santa Claus".[118] A version by José Ferrer had previously reached the Australian pop chart in 1961.

Title: "Yingle Bells"
Description: Peaked at No. 7 on Billboard's Best-Selling Pop Singles chart. Instrumental backing by the Johnny Duffy Trio. Parody of "Jingle Bells".[304][618]

Title: "You Make It Feel Like Christmas" (1)
Description: Peaked at No. 28 on Billboard's Adult Contemporary chart in 1985.[52][619] Originally appeared on Diamond's 1984 album Primitive, but later re-recorded and included on his 1992 holiday release, The Christmas Album.

Title: "You Make It Feel Like Christmas" (2)
Description: Peaked at No. 9 on the Billboard Adult Contemporary chart in early 2018, at No. 37 on the Billboard Holiday 100 chart, and at No. 3 on the Billboard Holiday Digital Song Sales chart.

Title: "You're a Mean One, Mr. Grinch"
Description: From the 1966 Dr. Seuss holiday TV special How the Grinch Stole Christmas! First entered Billboard's main Hot 100 chart at No. 49 on the week ending January 4, 2020, peaking at No. 31 on the week ending December 31, 2022 (upon its fourth chart re-entry). Also made these other Billboard music charts (with peak positions shown): Country Digital Song Sales (No. 23), Digital Song Sales (No. 33), Global 200 (No. 88), Holiday 100 (No. 14), Holiday Airplay (No. 14), Holiday Digital Song Sales (No. 2), Holiday Streaming Songs (No. 8), Hot 100 Recurrents (No. 3), Radio Songs (No. 49), and Streaming Songs (No. 25).[620]

Title: "You're a Mean One, Mr. Grinch"
Description: Peaked at No. 120 on the Billboard Bubbling Under Hot 100 chart on the week ending January 7, 1995.[56]

Title: "You're All I Want for Christmas" (1)
Description: Peaked at No. 11 on Billboard's Best-Selling Pop Singles chart in 1948 and No. 15 on Billboard's Race Records chart in 1949.[46][621] Written by Seger Ellis and Glen Moore. Also charted by Frank Gallagher in 1948.[137] Other versions recorded by Bing Crosby (1949), Eddie Fisher (1952),[58] Al Martino (1964),[48] Jackie Gleason (1967), and the Salsoul Orchestra (1981).

Title: "You're All I Want for Christmas" (2)
Description: Peaked at No. 3 on Billboard's Christmas Singles chart. Charted again in 1964. Featuring orchestration by Luchi DeJesus.[142] Different song than the same-titled hit by Frankie Laine from 1948. It was recorded in 1964 by Don Patterson for his album Holiday Soul. In 2011 Dutch singer Caro Emerald recorded a version, sampling Benton's original recording to produce a duet.

Title: "'Zat You, Santa Claus?"
Description: Peaked at No. 56 on Billboard's Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart in 2003.[73][622] Written by Jack Fox. Originally recorded by Louis Armstrong with the Commanders in 1953. Another popular version was released by Buster Poindexter in 1987.
